Show HN: Hacker News Mods - A collection of tools/mods for HN
text:
Hey HN! I built Hacker News Mods as a place to collect any tools or sites related to HN.

We just started building one mod/tool for HN per week, and I thought it’d be a good idea to showcase all of the tools we’ve created, as well as tools that others have created as well. The site is pretty scrappy, so any feedback is appreciated!

Also, please submit any projects that we don’t already have listed!

Thanks, Jarren

Ask HN: People who write a blog for fun, who do you have review your articles?
text:
Are there any good communities out there for hobbyist tech blog writers? Everything I've seen so far is just for people trying to make money off of their blog and is all about SEO/monetization. I write my blog just for fun, and I feel like it would be nice to get feedback and advice from people in the same boat. None of my friends are really into tech, so I hoped HN might know about some online communities?

Thanks,

Ask HN: Do you use an alias for OSS contributions?
text: Just curious how people contribute to open source projects which you don't really want your personal identity linked to. There's a few projects I'd like to submit contributions to, but I also don't want it to show up to prospective employers in the future. Does anyone use an alias for this kind of thing? And how do you go about setting up git/github/etc. to easily swap identities?

Ask HN: How will things work out this school year without an effective vaccine?
text:
If there is no vaccine for the now dominant BA.5 covid variant, what is going to happen this coming school year?

It seems like a pretty bad plan to stick the kids and teacher all in a room together. Why would teachers even sign up for this?

Low pay, low appreciation, near-guaranteed eventual covid infection.

The school districts in Oakland, CA have a massive number of vacant teaching positions they're becoming increasingly desperate to fill.

Arizona relaxed the requirements to allow anyone to teach as long as they're currently enrolled in college to become a teacher.

It seems crazy.

Ask HN: Should developing a programming language be a full time job?
text:
I've excitedly following the development of the Gleam programming language. The creator has recently switch to part time employment, to work on Gleam the rest of the time.

https://twitter.com/louispilfold/status/1547981946721951744

The language aims to be simple. Could there ever be a language is simple enough to get moderate adoption, without being anyone's full time job.
